Kintsugi(invisible, business, metaphor,:
- First image: A broken pottery bowl with three main pieces scattered around. The bowl has a blue base color with floral designs on it.
- Second image: A repaired pottery bowl using the Kintsugi technique, where the cracks are filled with gold, giving it a unique and artistic appearance.
- Relation: Repair and restoration of pottery.
- Explanation: The first image shows a broken pottery bowl, while the second image displays the same bowl after it has been repaired using the Kintsugi technique. This Japanese art form involves repairing broken pottery with lacquer mixed with powdered gold, silver, or platinum, which highlights the breaks and gives the piece a new life and beauty. The connection between the two images is the process of transforming a damaged object into a work of art through repair and restoration.

Six Sigma(invisible, business, relation,:
- First image: [Statistical process control chart comparing 3 Sigma and 6 Sigma curves]
- Second image: [Gage R&R (ANOVA) Report with various charts and graphs]
- Relation: [Quality control analysis]
- Explanation: Both images are related to quality control analysis in manufacturing or production processes. The first image compares the 3 Sigma and 6 Sigma curves, which are used to measure and improve the quality of a process by reducing variability. The second image is a Gage R&R (ANOVA) Report, which assesses the repeatability and reproducibility of measurements taken by different operators on the same part. This report helps identify sources of variation in the measurement process, ensuring that the data collected is accurate and reliable for quality control purposes.
Takt Time(invisible, business, relation,:

- Relation: Time measurement
- Explanation: Both images are related to the concept of time measurement. The first image deals with production times in a manufacturing context, specifically comparing Cycle Time (the time it takes to complete one unit of production) with Takt Time (the rate at which finished products need to be produced to meet customer demand).
